perturbation.original_text:
During the Term of this Agreement, each Party will maintain the following minimum types and amounts of insurance coverage during the Term of this Agreement:
a. Commercial General Liability Insurance. Occurrence based coverage with a combined single limit of at least $10,000,000 per occurrence and in the aggregate for premises and operations; products and completed operations; contractual liability coverage for indemnities of a Party contained within this Agreement; broad form property damage (including completed operations); explosion, collapse and underground hazards; and personal injury. Requires additional insured endorsement and waiver of subrogation endorsement.
perturbation.changed_text:
During the Term of this Agreement, each Party may, at their discretion, maintain insurance coverage.
a. Commercial General Liability Insurance.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the specific requirement to maintain minimum insurance coverage, the modified text contradicts general business and contractual norms and potentially applicable state laws requiring reasonable risk management and coverage for liabilities. This omission creates a legal loophole and exposes the parties to significant financial risks in case of accidents or damages.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of negligence and risk management; potentially specific state insurance regulations depending on the nature of the products and business operations covered by the agreement.
perturbation.law_explanation: The original text mandates specific insurance coverage, reflecting a standard practice to mitigate risks and ensure financial responsibility. The modified text, by removing these requirements, could violate the implicit duty of care and good faith, potentially leading to legal challenges related to negligence or breach of contract if adequate insurance is not maintained. 215 ILCS 5/143.13 is about unfair claim practices, which can be related to not having proper insurance.

perturbation.original_text: A Party will not suspend performance under or terminate this Agreement or any accepted purchase order for a product being purchased and sold under this Agreement unless: (1) the other Party is in material breach of this Agreement and has either refused to cure the material breach or has failed to cure the material breach within thirty (30) day of its receipt of written notice of the failure; and (2) the Parties have been unable to resolve the Dispute related to the material breach through negotiation or mediation, or the breaching Party has refused or failed to attempt to resolve the Dispute through negotiation or mediation, as provided in this Section.
perturbation.changed_text: A Party may suspend performance under or terminate this Agreement or any accepted purchase order for a product being purchased and sold under this Agreement at any time, for any reason, with no prior notice.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the requirement for a material breach and a cure period, and allowing termination "at any time, for any reason, with no prior notice" directly contradicts the principle of good faith and fair dealing implied in contracts under Illinois law. It allows for arbitrary termination, potentially harming the other party without recourse.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Uniform Commercial Code - Good Faith Obligation
perturbation.law_explanation: Illinois law, specifically the Uniform Commercial Code, imposes an obligation of good faith in the performance and enforcement of contracts. Removing the cure period and allowing termination for any reason violates this implied covenant, as it permits a party to act arbitrarily and without regard to the other party's interests and expectations. 810 ILCS 1/304 codifies this obligation.

perturbation.original_text: If Buyer fails to pay Seller an amount owed under this Agreement by the invoice due date, then Buyer will owe Seller: (i) the delinquent amount; and (ii) a late payment fee equal to two percent (2%) of the delinquent amount for each full or partial calendar month past the invoice due date that the delinquent amount remains unpaid. In addition, if Seller has to file litigation to collect the amount owed and Seller prevails in the litigation, Buyer will reimburse Seller for actual, reasonable, substantiated out-of-pocket expenses incurred by Seller in collecting the delinquent amount and accrued late payment fees on the delinquent amount. Under no circumstance will the late payment fee payable to Seller exceed the amount that a creditor may lawfully impose on a debtor on a delinquent amount under Applicable Law.
perturbation.changed_text: If Buyer fails to pay Seller an amount owed under this Agreement by the invoice due date, then Seller may take any action it deems necessary to collect the debt.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the explicit late payment fee structure and collection cost reimbursement, the modified text eliminates consumer protections against excessive or unlawful late fees.  This could violate usury laws or fair debt collection practices depending on the actions taken by the Seller.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Interest Act; Illinois Collection Agency Act
perturbation.law_explanation: The original text provides a specific and limited remedy for late payments, ensuring compliance with applicable laws. The modified text allows the Seller to take any action to collect the debt, potentially including actions that violate the Illinois Interest Act (815 ILCS 205/2), which regulates interest rates and charges on debts. The Illinois Collection Agency Act would also be applicable to third party collection agencies. The new text allows for the potential imposition of unreasonable fees.
